title.value: Lag-Llama: Towards Foundation Models for Time Series Forecasting
title.justification: Title is clearly given at the start of the paper
title.quote: Lag-Llama: Towards Foundation Models for Time Series Forecasting

extractions.description: This paper presents Lag-Llama, a univariate probabilistic time-series forecasting model trained on a large collection of time-series data. The paper studies the model's zero-shot prediction capabilities, performance on out-of-distribution datasets, and its scaling behavior. The model shows good zero-shot prediction capabilities on unseen datasets, outperforming several supervised baselines. Additionally, the study includes fitting neural scaling laws to predict the model's performance based on model size.

type.justification: The paper involves training and testing a new model, Lag-Llama, and it provides empirical results demonstrating its performance and scalability.

name.justification: The paper introduces Lag-Llama, a model specifically for univariate probabilistic time-series forecasting.
name.quote: Our strategy is to train a single model over a large corpus of time series, the details of which are in App. Table 4.

name.justification: The paper fits neural scaling laws to predict the performance of the model.
name.quote: We fit empirical scaling laws of the zero-shot test performance of the model as a function of the model size, allowing us to potentially extrapolate and predict generalization beyond the models used in this paper.

name.justification: The paper introduces and extensively discusses the Lag-Llama model.
name.quote: Lag-Llama’s zero-shot performance beats or compares favorably to supervised baselines, and as the model size increases, its performance improves and stabilizes across hyperparameter specifications.

is_contributed.justification: The model is newly introduced and studied in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: we aim to develop foundation models for time-series, investigate their behavior at scale, and push the limits of transfer achievable across diverse time-series domains. We train a transformer model on a large collection of time-series datasets and evaluate its performance on an unseen “out-of-distribution” dataset.
